#Text=Canada to legalise marijuana to ' make it more difficult for kids to access '
#Text=Sunday , April 16 , 2017

#Text=In order to put the cannabis drug ( marijuana ) out of reach of minors , the Canadian federal government announced a bill to legalise cannabis for the age group of eighteen and above , on Thursday .
#Text=The bill would allow adults to possess cannabis publicly , previously a criminal offence .
#Text=Canada 's health minister Jane Philpott tweeted , " Today we tabled new legislation to legalise , strictly regulate , and restrict access to cannabis .

#Text=Under-aged people can obtain the drug easily ; they said ,  it is easier for our kids to buy cannabis than cigarettes . "

column1: #Text=The bill allows provinces and territories to set the age limit above eighteen .
#Text=In order to prevent criminal gangs from making a profit , selling the drug needs a license permitting its sale .
#Text=Adults can purchase the drug online from a licensed producer if a retail shop is not available in the province .
#Text=Adults can carry up to 30 g ( slightly over an ounce ) of cannabis and grow at most four cannabis plants at home , for personal use .
#Text=The plants should be no taller than a metre , the bill proposed .
#Text=Selling cannabis to minors would be a specific criminal offence .
#Text=The legislation requires parliamentary approval and royal assent .
#Text=If passed , the bill would be under effect by July 2018 , the government said .
#Text=Health and safety experts and law enforcement were consulted before proposing the legislation .
#Text=Except for medical purposes , possession of the drug remains illegal until the bill is passed .
#Text=Regardless of the status of the bill , import and export of the drug would be illegal .
#Text=Previously when the government increased the taxes on cigarettes to discourage citizens from smoking , a black market for cigarettes developed .
#Text=Along with legalising cannabis , the bill would also permit the police officials to use tools like oral fluid drug screeners to detect if drivers are under the influence of the drug .
#Text=Zero tolerance against drivers under influence of drugs is proposed .
#Text=The government would also implement a public awareness campaign on the perils of driving under the influence of drugs .
#Text=The government still working on the restrictions .
#Text=Lawmaker and former police chief Bill Blair said , " We do accept that more important work remains to be done . "
#Text=If the bill is passed , Canada would be the second country to legalise cannabis completely .
#Text=Uruguay is the first .
#Text=Some countries , such as Germany , allow medical use of cannabis , but recreational use is prohibited .
